Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Biosensors Based on Electrogenerated Chemiluminescence
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this Career award, funded by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging program of the Division of Chemistry and the EPSCoR office, Professor Miao from the University of Southern Mississippi and his students will conduct research on biosensors based on electrogenerated chemiluminescence (ECL). The focus will be on simultaneous multiplexing ECL detection and quantification of biomolecules in a sample matrix with nanomaterials. The proposed detection scheme may allow for simultaneous measurements of 3-5 analytes without the need for target amplification or the use of enzymes. By using different types of ECL labels (hydrophobic, hydrophilic, and quantum dots), ECL detection can be performed in either organic or aqueous solutions, or in a solid-state format. Tools such as cyclic voltammetry, ECL coupled with scanning electrochemical microscopy, electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy, and electrochemical and ECL digital simulations will be used to achieve these objectives. Furthermore, investigation and preparation of nano-thickness Au film or Au nanoparticles (NPs) coatings for transparent electrodes for high performance ECL detection will be carried out. Finally, investigations of the photochemical, electrochemical, and ECL behavior as well as an exploration of sensing applications of templated micro- to nano-scale semiconductive metal chalcogenide films and NPs will be conducted.

ECL biosensors may find applications in clinical diagnostics, forensic chemistry, environmental investigations, pharmaceutical studies, and even in sensitive detection of high explosives and biological warfare agents - which is a pertinent issue in global security.

Professor Miao's research will be integrated with undergraduate and graduate education. In this context, an analytical ECL lab that is inexpensive, easy to operate, and adaptable to various levels of teaching and learning environments will be developed with an electrochemical instrument manufacture. In addition, in collaboration with colleagues from USM, Professor Miao will integrate instrumental analysis and inorganic as well as physical chemistry experiments into one senior undergraduate chemistry lab. The implementation of an integrative lab will serve as a model for other chemistry departments in the region and provide the opportunity to forge more robust relationships between USM and regional community colleges.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This funded project was allowed for the continuation of investigation into chemical sensors and biosensors based on electrogenerated chemiluminescence (ECL) as well as fundamental mechanistic studies of ECL systems. A variety of ECL-based detection strategies for ultrasensitive (i.e., toward a single-molecule detection level) and specific detection and quantification of species associated with e.g., environmental monitoring (Hg(II), 2,4,6-trinitrotoluene (TNT), and perfluorooctanoic acid), forensic sciences (TNT and cocaine), global security (TNT, triacetone triperoxide, and hexamethylene triperoxide diamine explosives), and clinic diagnosis (C-reactive protein, Zika virus, carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), alpha fetoprotein (AFP), DNA, and microRNA) using various ECL emitters including semiconductive nanocrystals (or quantum dots, QDs) were developed.

Our studies focused on dealing with some of the most important challenges in fabrication of an ultrasensitive and robust biosensor with outstanding specificity toward the target. These challenges include (a) effectively attaching the target-recognition element (probe) onto the electrode surface and maintaining its stability during redox cycling, (b) ensuring accessibility of the target to the probe and the efficiency of the redox reactions of the ECL coreactant at the probe−target assembled electrode, (c) designing and selecting the target-specific probe, (d) finding a signal-reporting element (i.e., ECL emitter) that directly correlates the analytical signal to the target concentration, and (e) determining a signal-amplification or quenching mechanism. For example, (1) to overcome the instability of the traditional Au-S binding, we reported (a) the C-N covalent coupling using a graphite electrode or a layer of activated carboxylic carbon nanotubes, and (b) the π-π stacking interactions between a tripod DNA and a graphene layer, resulting in construction of electrochemically stable and highly reusable ECL sensors for sensitive detection of e.g., cocaine, microRNA and Hg(II) ion. (2) Several strategies were employed to enhance the ECL signals via, for example, (a) dramatically increasing the molar ratio of the ECL emitter to the target without affecting the bioactivities of the probe and target by entrapping ECL emitters into dendrimers or polymer beads, (b) catalytically generating the ECL coreactant in situ, and (c) introducing subsequent hybridization chain reactions after the DNA or RNA hybridization so the efficient intercalation of the ECL emitter was promoted. (3) ECL quenching behavior of anodic coreactant ECL systems by chemically or electrochemically reducing species such as TNT and methylene blue was studied and used for detection of TNT and microRNA. (4) A set of QDs with high quantum yield values were synthesized and used as ECL emitters for (a) spectrum based ECL immunoassays and (b) simultaneous multiplexing analysis of biomolecules such as CEA mixed with AFP. (5) A systematic study of ECL mechanisms of both anodic and cathodic coreactant ECL systems was conducted, including (a) effects of carbon nanotubes on the ECL of CdTe QDs and (b) direct evidence acquired from electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy of several key short-lived radicals needed for ECL generation such as nitrate radical, benzoyloxy radical, persulfate anion radical, and 2-(dibutylamino)ethanol cation radical.

Several broader impacts resulting from this funded project were: (1) Changes and improvements of our undergraduate and graduate curricula. Theories and applications of chemiluminescence and ECL technology were introduced to both lectures and labs of Analytical Chemistry, Instrumental Analysis, and Electroanalytical Chemistry. Teaching topics related to QDs enabled us to fulfill partially the requirements made by the Committee on Professional Training of the American Chemical Society on "Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanoscale (MSN) Systems in the Curriculum". (2) Education and professional training of undergraduate and graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, and visiting scholars especially those from underrepresented groups led us to produce high quality professionals, many of whom are now in graduate or professional schools or serving in the States and overseas as research scientists or college/university professors. (3) Establishment of wide collaborative research network allowed us to extend ECL sensors to a much broad applied area and to publish many high-quality papers. (4) Findings obtained from this project were directly beneficial to our society as demonstrated by their applications in the areas of e.g., disease biomarker detection, Zika virus quantification, cocaine verification, and high explosive identification.
